text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Two Kiambu residents are killed as they answer a distress call in another bloody gang terror that leaves scores wounded.
- Sheikh Khalid Balala, exiled leader of the unregistered Islamic Party of Kenya, is issued with internationally valid travel documents by the German government and is set to return to Kenya.
- A woman is arrested over the lynching of a security guard among 100 people sent to demolish a slum in Lavington, Nairobi.
- The unregistered Safina party denies having incited recent riots at Egerton University as alleged by the vice-chancellor.
- Nairobi branch of the Kenya Union of Commercial Food and Allied Workers dismisses as null and void elections held at the weekend.
- A suspected witch narrowly escapes death in Kitui town.
- Villagers armed with spears kill an elephant outside a game reserve in Keiyo district.
- An armed gangster seriously wounds a police officer in an abortive robbery in Machakos town.
- Kenyan transporters say Tanzania is blocking the delivery of relief supplies to Rwandan refugee camps in an effort to hasten their repatriation.
- The Ugandan government is to set up a body to regulate the private generating of electricity once the sector is liberalised.
- Roman Catholic bishops from the Great Lakes region express concern about the disappearance of a former bishop of Ruhengeri in northwest Rwanda.
